title: 110_hr6842
content:
The "Second Amendment Enforcement Act" is the short title of the Act. Congressional findings are outlined in the Act. Congress finds that the Second Amendment protects the rights of individuals to keep and bear arms, including law-abiding citizens in the District of Columbia who are deprived of firearms commonly used for sporting and self-defense. The District of Columbia has the highest per capita murder rate in the Nation, attributed in part to local laws prohibiting possession of firearms by law-abiding persons. Federal regulations and existing criminal laws already address possession and illegal use of firearms by violent criminals and felons, making local laws unnecessary and disarming law-abiding citizens. Legislation is needed to correct the District of Columbia's restrictive firearm laws, which violate citizens' Second Amendment rights and hinder public safety. SEC. 3. REFORM D.C. COUNCIL'S AUTHORITY TO RESTRICT FIREARMS. Section 4 of the Act prohibits the District of Columbia from enacting laws that restrict or discourage private ownership or use of firearms not prohibited by Federal law. The Act prohibits the District of Columbia from restricting private ownership or use of firearms, except for regulating carrying outside of certain locations. SEC. 4. REPEAL D.C. SEMIAUTOMATIC BAN. The Firearms Control Regulations Act of 1975 is amended to redefine a machine gun as a firearm that can shoot automatically more than 1 shot without manual reloading. Additionally, criminal penalties related to this definition are also amended. The definition of a machine gun in the Firearms Control Regulations Act of 1975 is amended to align with section 101(10) of the Act. SEC. 5. REPEAL REGISTRATION REQUIREMENT. Repeal of Requirement: The Firearms Control Regulations Act of 1975 is amended to describe illegal firearms as sawed-off shotguns, machine guns, and short-barreled rifles. The heading of the Act is changed to "Firearm Possession." The Firearms Control Regulations Act of 1975 is amended by repealing sections 202 through 211 and making amendments to sections 101 and 401 regarding firearm possession and ammunition loading. The Firearms Control Regulations Act of 1975 is amended to update registration requirements for firearms, including changes to sections 402 and 401. The Firearms Control Regulations Act of 1975 is amended to update registration requirements for firearms, including changes to sections 402 and 401. The amendments include updating the applicant's name requirement and changing references from "registration certificate" to "dealer's license" in section 403(b). Additionally, amendments in section 404(a)(3) involve removing references to the registration certificate number and updating language related to firearm repair. Section 406(c) of the Firearms Control Regulations Act is amended to require licensees to remove destructive devices from inventory within 45 days of an unfavorable decision. Additionally, they must lawfully dispose of firearms and ammunition. Section 407(b) is amended to prohibit individuals from possessing firearms. Section 502 of the Firearms Control Regulations Act is amended to allow the sale or transfer of firearms and ammunition by licensed dealers to individuals not prohibited from possessing them under Federal or District law. Amendments include removing certain paragraphs and subsections. Section 502 of the Firearms Control Regulations Act is amended to allow the sale or transfer of firearms and ammunition by licensed dealers to individuals not prohibited from possessing them under Federal or District law. This includes amendments to Section 704 of the D.C. Official Code, removing certain registration requirements and conforming amendments to the Illegal Firearm Sale and Distribution Strict Liability Act of 1992. SEC. 6. REPEAL HANDGUN AMMUNITION BAN. Amends section 601(3) of the Firearms Control Regulations Act to allow ownership of ammunition without a registration certificate.

SEC. 7. RESTORE RIGHT OF SELF DEFENSE IN THE HOME. Repeals section 702 of the Firearms Control Regulations Act, restoring the right of self-defense in the home.

SEC. 8. REMOVE CRIMINAL PENALTIES FOR POSSESSION OF UNREGISTERED FIREARMS. Removes criminal penalties for possession of unregistered firearms. SEC. 8. Remove criminal penalties for possession of unregistered firearms. Amends section 706 of the Firearms Control Regulations Act to eliminate penalties for possessing unregistered firearms. Effective for violations occurring after a 60-day period from the enactment of this Act. SEC. 10 amends the Act of July 8, 1932 to allow residents of the District to purchase firearms. It also makes amendments regarding the possession of firearms in certain locations. SEC. 10 amends Section 922 of title 18, United States Code to allow residents of the District of Columbia to purchase handguns from licensees in Maryland or Virginia.
